Source code for new_kedro_project.pipelines.data_engineering.nodes

"""Example code for the nodes in the example pipeline. This code is meant
just for illustrating basic Kedro features.

PLEASE DELETE THIS FILE ONCE YOU START WORKING ON YOUR OWN PROJECT!
"""

from typing import Any, Dict

import pandas as pd



[docs]def split_data(data: pd.DataFrame, example_test_data_ratio: float) -> Dict[str, Any]:
    """Node for splitting the classical Iris data set into training and test
    sets, each split into features and labels.
    The split ratio parameter is taken from conf/project/parameters.yml.
    The data and the parameters will be loaded and provided to your function
    automatically when the pipeline is executed and it is time to run this node.
    """
    import logging
    logging.info("Start1")
    data.columns = [
        "sepal_length",
        "sepal_width",
        "petal_length",
        "petal_width",
        "target",
    ]
    logging.info("Start2")
    classes = sorted(data["target"].unique())
    # One-hot encoding for the target variable
    data = pd.get_dummies(data, columns=["target"], prefix="", prefix_sep="")
    logging.info("Start3")
    # Shuffle all the data
    data = data.sample(frac=1).reset_index(drop=True)
    logging.info("Start4")
    # Split to training and testing data
    n = data.shape[0]
    n_test = int(n * example_test_data_ratio)
    training_data = data.iloc[n_test:, :].reset_index(drop=True)
    test_data = data.iloc[:n_test, :].reset_index(drop=True)

    # Split the data to features and labels
    train_data_x = training_data.loc[:, "sepal_length":"petal_width"]
    train_data_y = training_data[classes]
    test_data_x = test_data.loc[:, "sepal_length":"petal_width"]
    test_data_y = test_data[classes]

    # When returning many variables, it is a good practice to give them names:
    return dict(
        train_x=train_data_x,
        train_y=train_data_y,
        test_x=test_data_x,
        test_y=test_data_y,
    )
